Why, after (depending on how you count) is printing press technology still in development after over 500 or 1200 years?Those are not satirical retorts. They go to one of the fundamentals of technology development, which is that human imagination is always finding ways to improve any class of technology. Printing presses were slow and inflexible when first invented, but people keep coming up with new ways to make printing faster, more flexible, less expensive, and, in general, more adaptive to the varied uses that we have for printing. The same is true for telephones (interactive voice technology) and light bulbs (light technology), which have changed radically in my lifetime. The same is true for all inventions, including AI and blockchain.Between them, AI technologies are older, with a history that goes back almost 70 years, a history of use in entertainment for about 50 years (starting with Eliza), and a history of practical use that goes back a little over 30 years (starting, by my accounting, with rule-based decision systems that could take practical action using the event-condition-action) model. I’m sure there are those who would say that such programs aren’t “AI”, but they were certainly a practical step forward towards the systems we have today. It continues to be developed because we can imagine improvements (or at least developments) in AI that we haven’t made yet. It remains that we continue to find ways to make AI technologies faster, more flexible, less expensive, and, in general, more adaptive to the varied uses that we have for machine intelligence. That won’t stop because machine intelligence technologies reach the holy grail of “self awareness” (if we ever reach that goal) or machine intelligences become capable of improving themselves (a more practical and readily achieved goal. If it stops it will be because of a failure of human imagination.Blockchain is newer. The first blockchain system that I’m aware of is about 20 years old now. Imagining it required developments in programming, networks, and computer capabilities (processor speed and memory) that came together at about that time. It is a very young technology that is currently used to solve a limited number of problems. And in the most public of its applications (the representation of value/money) it has strongly entrenched competition (physical money, for instance) that retains considerable advantages, especially for people that don’t carry electronic devices around in their pockets. That will undoubtedly change over the (one hopes) next 500 or 1200 years as we continue to find ways to make blockchain technologies faster, more flexible, less expensive, and, in general, more adaptive to the varied uses that we have for blockchain.I don’t want to say this was a silly question, but the truth is that all inventions evolve over time. Doing that requires continuing development. That’s just the way times arrow works in the universe we live in.
